questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient follows up in your OPD , 1 month after you performed distal gastrectomy with Billroth II reconstruction for his perforated gastric ulcer. The histopathology report does not show any evidence of malignancy. On her follow up visit he no longer has the burning epigastric pain, but complains of bloating and severe abdominal cramps soon after meals, followed by profuse diarrhea, sweating,and dizziness. These symptoms appeared shortly after he recovered from surgery, and have not improved since then. He can be advised all of the following except

options.label: A
options.text: With dietary modifications majority of these symptoms will improve

options.label: B
options.text: He should separate the ingestion of liquids from solids

options.label: C
options.text: Administration of cholestyramine will likely prevent most of his symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: None of the surgical treatments of this condition is uniformly successful.

questions.correct_answer: C. Administration of cholestyramine will likely prevent most of his symptoms

questions.text: All the following statements about autoimmune gastritis are true except

options.label: A
options.text: Antibodies to parietal cells and Intrinsic Factor are seen in gastric secretions.

questions.correct_answer: B. Serum pepsinogen concentration is increased.

questions.text: False about Menetrier’s disease is

options.label: A
options.text: Diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar mucus cells.

questions.correct_answer: C. Antral involvement is very common

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for Adeno Ca stomach

options.label: B
options.text: PGDFRA (Platelet derived growth factor receptor alpha) mutation

options.label: D
options.text: Germline mutation in CDH1 coding for E cadherin

questions.correct_answer: B. PGDFRA (Platelet derived growth factor receptor alpha) mutation

questions.text: Which of the following does not affect gastrin release

A 50 year old male with a history of peptic ulcer presents to the emergency with haematemesis. Upper GI endoscopy reveals active pulsatile bleeding from a posteriorly located duodenal ulcer. Even after two attempts of controlling the bleeding endoscopically, the bleeding continues. The patient has received four units of blood. His hematocrit is 28%, his pulse rate is 114/min and blood pressure is 112/64 mm Hg. The most appropriate management in this patient should be?

options.label: B
options.text: Duodenotomy , oversewing the ulcer, truncal vagotomy and antrectomy

options.label: C
options.text: Duodenotomy, oversewing the ulcer, truncal vagotomy, and pyloroplasty

options.label: D
options.text: Duodenotomy , oversewing the ulcer and HSV

questions.correct_answer: C. Duodenotomy, oversewing the ulcer, truncal vagotomy, and pyloroplasty

questions.correct_answer: A. Mesenteroaxial volvulus has a more acute presentation.

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: C. Organoaxial volvulus has less chance of necrosis as compared to mesenteroaxial volvulus.

A 30 years old male presented with massive hematemesis. A 2 × 2 cm ulcer was visualized on upper GI endoscopy on the posterior aspect of first part of duodenum. The bleeding vessel was visualized but bleeding could not be controlled endoscopically. Blood transfusion was done and patient was planned for surgery. His BP was 90/70mmhg and PR=110/min with Hb=9 gm% at the time of surgery. Which of the following would be best surgical management?

options.label: A
options.text: Antrectomy with ligation of left gastric artery

options.label: B
options.text: Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels with postoperative PPI

options.label: C
options.text: Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels, truncal vagotomy and pyloroplasty

options.label: D
options.text: Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels, highly selective vagotomy

questions.correct_answer: B. Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels with postoperative PPI

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with a history of projectile, non-bilious vomiting for the past 5 days. The baby appears dehydrated, and laboratory investigations reveal the following: • Sodium: 132 mmol/L (low) • Potassium: 2.8 mmol/L (low) • Chloride: 85 mmol/L (low) • pH: 7.55 (alkalosis) Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is MOST characteristic of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS)?
A 2-day-old neonate presents with bilious vomiting since birth. An abdominal X-ray reveals the following sign. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male presents with epigastric pain, nausea, and occasional vomiting for the past 3 months. He reports that the pain worsens after meals. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the BEST investigation to confirm the diagnosis of a gastric ulcer and rule out malignancy?
questions.correct_answer: C. Upper GI endoscopy with biopsy

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with sudden-onset severe epigastric pain. He has a history of long-standing epigastric discomfort and occasional use of NSAIDs. On examination, he has tachycardia, hypotension, and guarding in the abdomen. Which of the following is the most common complication of peptic ulcers?

A 40-year-old male presents with recurrent epigastric pain, chronic diarrhea, and significant weight loss over the past 6 months. He has been treated for multiple episodes of peptic ulcers in the past, but symptoms have recurred despite regular use of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). Laboratory tests reveal a fasting gastrin level of 1200 pg/mL (normal: <100 pg/mL). What is the MOST likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male with a history of recurrent, refractory peptic ulcer disease is diagnosed with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES). Imaging studies are planned to localize the gastrinoma. Which of the following anatomical regions is referred to as Passaro's Triangle, where most gastrinomas are found?

options.label: A
options.text: Between the esophagus, stomach, and spleen

options.label: B
options.text: Between the cystic duct, duodenum, and pancreatic body

options.label: C
options.text: Between the porta hepatis, neck of the pancreas, and third part of the duodenum

options.label: D
options.text: Between the liver, spleen, and greater curvature of the stomach

questions.correct_answer: C. Between the porta hepatis, neck of the pancreas, and third part of the duodenum
